column1: #Text=The West Highland Way ( or W.H.W. ) is a 95 mile ( 152 km ) long-distance walk from Milngavie outside Glasgow , to Fort William in the Highlands of Scotland .
#Text=It is one of four officially-recognised " Long-Distance Routes " in Scotland .

column1: #Text=Although it is of course possible to walk from Fort William to Milngavie , the general advice is to use the more gentle terrain in the south as a warm-up to the remote and dramatic mountain areas further north , plus you will have the sun behind you .
#Text=Milngavie is best reached from Glasgow city centre .
#Text=Regular bus and local train services depart throughout the day from Buchanan Street Bus Station and Queen Street Railway Station respectively .
#Text=The Kelvin Walkway is the best route if you wish to cycle or walk from the city .
#Text=Fort William has a three times daily train service and three times daily bus service both to Glasgow .
#Text=Generally , people take anything between 6 and 9 days to complete the W.H.W . , with the position of overnight accommodation determining daily mileages .
#Text=The opening stretch of the walk from Milngavie to Drymen is a loosener through soft and pleasant agricultural countryside .
#Text=The first section from Drymen to Balmaha takes you through the managed pines of Garadhban Forest , where you catch your first glimpse of Loch Lomond .
#Text=From the forest you emerge into the Highlands , an unfarmable landscape carved by glaciers .
#Text=Feast on the view from the top of Conic Hill .
#Text=The stretch from Balmaha to Inverarnan takes in the entire length of Loch Lomond 's remote and wooded eastern shore .
#Text=In May and early June the steep bank is wall-to-wall bluebells .
#Text=When the sun is out , small sandy beaches invite you to swim .
#Text=Inverarnan to the Inveroran Hotel is possibly the easiest stretch of the walk .
#Text=The path is wide and gently undulating .
#Text=Peaks rise above you giving the first clue of the wild , mountainous scenery to come .
#Text=From the Inveroran Hotel you walk up onto the unfeasibly beautiful Rannoch Moor .
#Text=Lovers of lonely desolation will catch their breath .
#Text=The path across the moor brings you out at the Kings House Hotel , a speck at the foot of the astonishing Glen Coe .
#Text=From the Kings House Hotel the " Devil 's Staircase " takes you up and over into Kinlochleven .
#Text=From Kinlochleven a steady climb takes you up into Lairigmoor , a pristine glacial valley .
#Text=An optional scramble half way up one of the peaks on the northern side reveals the full beauty of this place .
#Text=From Lairigmor the path snakes North into managed woodland .
#Text=A couple of tiring but short climbs and the path takes you over into Glen Nevis , from where the going into Fort William is easy .
#Text=The Fort William end of the walk connects with the Great Glen Way , which runs a further 73 miles ( 118 km ) to Inverness .
#Text=Though it passes through mountainous country and fine scenery , the Way is n't a mountain walk .
#Text=The path is generally very good and easy to navigate , and any given section of the Way would simply be a pleasant stroll .
#Text=The difficulty comes with the endurance required to walk all day every day for a week .
#Text=There is a range of hotels , B&Bs , bunkhouses , simple shelters and campsites along the way .
#Text=Expect to pay £30-60 per night , in the high season , for bed and breakfast at both hotels and B&Bs .
#Text=Highlights include the historic King 's House Hotel in stunning Glen Coe , where a bunkhouse bed starts at around £25 .
#Text=You can expect to pay around £10 - £20 for a bunkhouse bed with breakfast .
#Text=( 10 miles by bus from the Kings House Hotel at mile 72 )
#Text=A backpacker 's pitch at a serviced campsite ( i.
#Text=e. one providing water , showers , toilets etc ) costs around £7 .
#Text=If this is your preferred option , a choice must be made between a shortish ( 11 mi ) or longish ( 20 mi ) first day .
#Text=If you choose the latter , conic hill around mile 17 , whilst a first taste of the scenic beauty to come , is a heartbreaker .
#Text=Also note that a long second day to Ardlui or Inverarnan then follows .
#Text=After that the sites are well spaced .
#Text=The pick of the bunch is Beinglass Farm at Inverarnan .
#Text=Basically it 's an excellent bar/restaurant with a campsite and camping shop attached .
#Text=The Millarochy site is also recommended for its lovely spot on Loch Lomond .
#Text=Walkers may wild camp for free in small numbers except in enclosed fields of crops or near farm animals but all traces of the camp must be removed ( see www.outdooraccess-scotland.com ) .
#Text=Wild camping is not permitted between Drymen and Balmaha .
#Text=These bylaws were introduced following excessive litter and noise in these areas .
#Text=is permitted in other areas on the shore of Loch Lomond .
#Text=Water presents the main difficulty with this option .

#Text=Consuming water from the many streams ( or " burns " ) along the way is said to be " high risk at low level " ( unless there has been lots of rain ) because of the cows and sheep on the hills , although boiling the water will provide a measure of protection .
#Text=The safest option is to bring water from the nearest drinkable source .
#Text=This means hauling a lot of weight but , if you pick the right spot , it can be worth it for the solitude .
#Text=Designated wild campsites close to drinkable water can be found at Rowardennan Lodge , Inversnaid and Kings House Hotel .

#Text=Inexplicably , King 's House Hotel is the only sleeping/dining option in that 20 mile stretch of the walk , and it reserves months in advance , causing walkers to have to resort to taxi rides to other towns , and a similar return the next morning to resume the walk ; this is most inconvenient and should be fixed .
#Text=Finally there are two bothies en route , Rowchoish and Doune , both on Loch Lomond .
#Text=These are basically stone shelters without running water and so offer wild camping without the need for a tent .
